title: Canadian giant says policy certainty drives infrastructure investment
text:
"As a buyer of these assets, we are pricing in an expectation of stability of regulation, stability of taxation and that's what we expect from a developed market like Australia so we can bid really competitively and get the best price.

"The answer is 'don't change'."

Value for money

There have been concerns about tolls rising faster than wage growth, and that increasingly busy toll roads may not be delivering the value and benefits to consumers they may have in the past.

Mr Machin said it was a concern that CPPIB monitored closely, and that as a consumer-facing business it needed to show value for money to maintain daily traffic volumes.

"People need to see the value that they're getting from the tolls or the fees they're paying," he said.

"We need to be sensitive to consumer demand and the value they're getting from each of the assets."

CPPIB is among the larger infrastructure and property investors in Australia, with $C13.6 billion ($15.2 billion) committed to projects such as toll road WestConnex.

Advertisement

However, Mr Machin lamented the dearth of scale renewable energy investments available in Australia. CPPIB, which typically likes to make an investment of $C500 million, has invested in renewable energy projects in the US, Europe and emerging markets such as Brazil.

Unfortunately, it has yet to find an opportunity here that offers the scale it is seeking.

"If there is a scale platform that comes along, then we would certainly be interested in that," Mr Machin said.

CPPIB is an investor in carbon capture infrastructure, having invested more than $C300 million in the Alberta Carbon Trunk Line.

The pipeline will take about 20 per cent of all carbon dioxide emissions produced by the oil sands industry and inject them into ageing reservoirs.

Mr Machin said there were "some provincial subsidies to make the economics work".
description: Canada Pension Plan Investment Board CEO Mark Machin says Australia is the "poster child" for asset recycling, thanks to regulatory and tax policy certainty.
